clean_story:
Microwaves. Popcorn’s accidental hero.

Percy Spencer’s name isn’t on your microwave—but his curiosity is.
A radar engineer at Raytheon in 1945, he noticed a candy bar in his pocket melted near a magnetron tube.
Instead of shrugging, he tested popcorn kernels.
They exploded.
Next, an egg—it burst in a colleague’s face.
Spencer didn’t invent microwaves, but he harnessed them.
By 1947, Raytheon patented the first microwave oven: 6 feet tall, 750 pounds, costing $5,000.
Hospitals and ships used it first—too bulky for homes.
His breakthrough? Controlled chaos.
Microwaves agitate water molecules, heating food from within.
No flames, no pans—just energy, repurposed.
Spencer, an orphan with no formal education, held 150 patents.
His microwave was a side effect of radar tech meant for war.
Now, 90% of U. S. homes have one.
Serendipity in science.
Orphaned genius.
War tech turned kitchen staple.
